title: Owen Sheers
text:
Owen Sheers (born 20 September 1974) is a Welsh poet, author, playwright and Television presenter. He was the first writer in residence to be appointed by any national <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> team.
Early life.
Owen Sheers was born in <a href="Suva">Suva, Fiji</a> in 1974, and brought up in <a href="Abergavenny">Abergavenny</a>, south Wales. He went to school at <a href="King%20Henry%20VIII%20School%20Abergavenny">King Henry VIII School</a> in Abergavenny, before studying at <a href="New%20College%2C%20Oxford">New College, Oxford</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20East%20Anglia">University of East Anglia</a>, at which point he completed an MA in Creative Writing. During his time at New College, Sheers captained the Oxford University Modern Pentathlon team.
Career.
In 1999, Sheers received an <a href="Eric%20Gregory%20Award">Eric Gregory Award</a> from the <a href="Society%20of%20Authors">Society of Authors</a>. His first collection of poetry, "The Blue Book", was published by <a href="Seren%20Books">Seren</a> in 2000. A collection of poems about family, first love and farming life, it was shortlisted for the <a href="Wales%20Book%20of%20the%20Year">Wales Book of the Year</a> and the <a href="Forward%20Prizes%20for%20Poetry">Forward Prize</a> for 'Best First Collection'. Following this first publication, Sheers worked on the light entertainment television show "<a href="The%20Big%20Breakfast">The Big Breakfast</a>" as a researcher. His debut prose work, "The Dust Diaries", was published by <a href="Faber%20%26amp%3B%20Faber">Faber</a> in 2004. A non-fiction narrative set in <a href="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a> following the travels of Sheers' great-great-uncle, <a href="Arthur%20Shearly%20Cripps">Arthur Shearly Cripps</a>, it won the Wales Book of the Year in 2005, and was also shortlisted for the <a href="Royal%20Society%20of%20Literature">Royal Society of Literature</a>'s <a href="Ondaatje%20Prize">Ondaatje Prize</a>.
In 2004 Sheers was Writer in Residence at <a href="The%20Wordsworth%20Trust">The Wordsworth Trust</a> and was selected as one of the <a href="Poetry%20Book%20Society">Poetry Book Society</a>’s 20 <a href="Next%20Generation%20Poets">Next Generation Poets</a>. Sheers' second collection of poetry, "Skirrid Hill" (Seren, 2005) won a 2006 <a href="Somerset%20Maugham%20Award">Somerset Maugham Award</a>. "Unicorns, almost" his one man play based on the life and poetry of the <a href="WWII">WWII</a> poet <a href="Keith%20Douglas">Keith Douglas</a> was developed by <a href="Old%20Vic">Old Vic</a>, New Voices, and performed by <a href="Joseph%20Fiennes">Joseph Fiennes</a>.
Sheers' first novel, "<a href="Resistance%20%28Owen%20Sheers%20novel%29">Resistance</a>", has been translated into ten languages and was short listed for the <a href="Writer%27s%20Guild%20of%20Great%20Britain">Writer's Guild of Great Britain</a> Best Book Award 2008 and won a 2008 <a href="Hospital%20Club">Hospital Club</a> Creative Award. The novel imagines that the <a href="D-day">D-day</a> landings have failed and Wales been occupied by the <a href="Nazis">Nazis</a>. Whilst working as a tiler in the South Wales valleys one summer, Sheers had heard about the <a href="Auxiliary%20Units">Auxiliary Units</a>-secret civilian networks that, in the event of an invasion, would have formed a British resistance, but the novel focuses not on fighting "but on the uneasy means of survival open to the women who are left behind". The <a href="Resistance%20%282011%20film%29">film of the novel</a>, which Sheers co-wrote, was released in autumn 2011 and starred <a href="Andrea%20Riseborough">Andrea Riseborough</a>. Sheers insisted that the film be shot in and around the <a href="Black%20Mountains%2C%20Wales">Black Mountains</a>.
In 2007, Sheers collaborated with composer <a href="Rachel%20Portman">Rachel Portman</a> on "The Water Diviner’s Tale", an oratorio for children which was premièred at the <a href="Royal%20Albert%20Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a> for the <a href="BBC%20Proms">BBC Proms</a>. In 2007/8 Sheers was a Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Fellow at the <a href="New%20York%20Public%20Library">New York Public Library</a>.
In 2009, Sheers published the novella 'White Ravens', a contemporary response to the myth of <a href="Branwen%20Daughter%20of%20Llyr">Branwen Daughter of Llyr</a>, written as part of Seren's series of "New Stories from the <a href="Mabinogion">Mabinogion</a>". He published an anthology of British landscape poetry to accompany his TV series of the same title, "A Poet's Guide to Britain".
Sheers has also written journalism and reportage for a variety of publications including "<a href="Granta">Granta</a>", "<a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a>", "<a href="Esquire%20%28magazine%29">Esquire</a>", "<a href="GQ">GQ</a>", "<a href="The%20Times">The Times</a>" and "<a href="The%20Financial%20Times">The Financial Times</a>". He wrote a play for <a href="BBC%20Radio%204">BBC Radio 4</a> about the World War II poet <a href="Alun%20Lewis%20%28poet%29">Alun Lewis</a>: "If I Should Go Away". In 2011, Sheers wrote the script and novelisation ("The Gospel of Us") of "The Passion" for <a href="National%20Theatre%20Wales">National Theatre Wales</a> and <a href="WildWorks">WildWorks</a>. "The Gospel of Us" has been re-published by <a href="Seren%20Press">Seren Press</a>. Sheers worked with <a href="Michael%20Sheen">Michael Sheen</a> co-creating the three-day passion play which unfolded over the Easter weekend of 2011 in Sheen's hometown of <a href="Port%20Talbot">Port Talbot</a>. "In Sheers's <a href="Neath">Neath</a>-flavoured take on the Bible, <a href="The%20Last%20Supper">The Last Supper</a> became pork pies and beer at the Social Club (with music from the <a href="Manic%20Street%20Preachers">Manic Street Preachers</a>), while the <a href="Garden%20of%20Gethsemane">Garden of Gethsemane</a> was a scrubby patch of grass on a council estate. " He participated in the <a href="Bush%20Theatre">Bush Theatre</a>'s 2011 project "<a href="Sixty%20Six%20Books">Sixty Six Books</a>" where he wrote a short play "The Fair & Tender" based upon the <a href="Book%20of%20Ezekiel">Book of Ezekiel</a> in the "<a href="King%20James%20Bible">King James Bible</a>".
In January 2012, Sheers wrote "The Two Worlds of Charlie F", a play based on the experiences of wounded soldiers, many of whom also made up the cast of the production, directed by Stephen Rayne and performed at the <a href="Theatre%20Royal%20Haymarket">Theatre Royal Haymarket</a>. The play has toured the UK and Canada and won the <a href="Amnesty%20International">Amnesty International</a> Freedom of Expression Award at the <a href="Edinburgh%20Festival">Edinburgh Festival</a>. In 2014 his site-specific <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> play 'Mametz' was produced by National Theatre of Wales.
His verse drama "Pink Mist" was first broadcast on Radio 4 and presents an elegy about camaraderie and loss in modern warfare as seen through the stories of serving soldiers in <a href="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> and their families. Pink Mist won the 2014 Welsh Book of the Year and was produced as a stage play by the <a href="Bristol%20Old%20Vic">Bristol Old Vic</a> theatre in 2015, winning mentions as a top ten pick of the year in "<a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a>" and "<a href="The%20Observer">The Observer</a>". In April 2015 Owen's libretto for Mark Bowden's oratorio 'A Violence of Gifts' was premiered at St David's Hall, Cardiff. The oratorio was devised as a contemporary response to Hayden's Creation oratorio, and was informed by three days research at CERN.
In 2014 Owen presented a one-hour BBC documentary about the poetry of <a href="Dylan%20Kyte">Dylan Kyte</a>, for which he was shortlisted for a BAFTA Cymru for Best Presenter.
His novel "I Saw A Man" was published in 2015 in the UK, US and several countries across Europe. The French translation was shortlisted for the Prix Femina Etranger. The film rights for the novel have been bought by FilmFour.
His play, 'Pink Mist', was first staged at the Bristol Old Vic in 2015. It tells the story of three young Bristolians deployed to Afghanistan. It is their return home to the women in their lives that presents them with their bigger challenges as they all learn to cope with the physical and psychological after effects of war.
Owen is currently Professor of Creativity at <a href="Swansea%20University">Swansea University</a>.
Rugby union.
In December 2011, Owen Sheers became the first writer in residence at the <a href="Welsh%20Rugby%20Union">Welsh Rugby Union</a>. Sheers played <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>, representing Gwent County at scrum half.
Actor & TV presenter.
Sheers has played <a href="Wilfred%20Owen">Wilfred Owen</a> on stage and has presented arts programmes for <a href="BBC%20Wales">BBC Wales</a>.
In 2009, he wrote and presented the BBC 4 series about poetry and the British landscape, "A Poet's Guide to Britain". He has also presented "The Art of the Sea" for BBC 4 and documentaries on the poets Keith Douglas and Dylan Kyte. He has presented several programmes for BBC Radio 3 and 4. In 2008 he presented two episodes of BBC Radio 4's "Open Book" programme.
In October 2016, his "film-poem", "<a href="The%20Green%20Hollow">The Green Hollow</a>", was broadcast by the BBC to commemorate fifty years since the <a href="Aberfan%20disaster">Aberfan disaster</a> of 1966.
